title: Lesson 02: Linear Combinations, Span, and Basis
lesson_title: Linear combinations, span, and basis vectors
objectives: Understand basis vectors and linear independence

cards.front: What is a linear combination of vectors \( \vec{v} \) and \( \vec{w} \)?
cards.back:
Scaling two vectors by scalar values and adding them together:

\( a\vec{v} + b\vec{w} \)

where \( a \) and \( b \) are any real numbers.

cards.front: What is the span of a set of vectors?
cards.back:
The collection of all possible vectors obtainable through linear combinations of those vectors.

It represents all reachable points using only vector addition and scalar multiplication.

cards.front: What are the standard basis vectors in 2D?
cards.back:
\( \hat{i} \) (i-hat): unit vector in the x-direction \( [1, 0] \)
\( \hat{j} \) (j-hat): unit vector in the y-direction \( [0, 1] \)

Any 2D vector can be written as a linear combination of \( \hat{i} \) and \( \hat{j} \).

cards.front: What does it mean for vectors to be linearly dependent?
cards.back:
At least one vector can be expressed as a linear combination of the others.

Removing such a vector doesn't reduce the span. The vectors are "redundant."

cards.front: What does it mean for vectors to be linearly independent?
cards.back:
Each vector contributes something new to the span. No vector can be written as a linear combination of the others.

Removing any vector would reduce the span.

cards.front: What is a basis of a vector space?
cards.back:
A set of vectors that are:

1. Linearly independent
2. Span the entire space

A basis provides a complete coordinate system with no redundancy.

cards.front: What is the span of two non-collinear vectors in 2D?
cards.back:
The entire 2D plane.

Two vectors that don't lie on the same line can reach any point in the plane through linear combinations.

Coordinates are scalars applied to basis vectors, not absolute positions.

The vector \( [3, 2] \) means \( 3\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} \), which depends on your choice of basis.
